instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00163: What is 820-00163? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SPI_MLBROM_CS_L: What is SPI_MLBROM_CS_L? SPI_MLBROM_CS_L is a signal that goes between the SPI ROM chip and another chip on machines with quad SPI, that can frequently corrode on 13‚Äù Macbook Air from 2015 because it is near the corner where liquid seeps in. This being corroded can stop PM_SLP_S4_L from being present. .
definitions.SPI_MOSI: What is SPI_MOSI? SPI_MOSI is a signal between the CPU or PCH and the SPI ROM bios chip that is necessary for the machine to POST and boot. If this signal line is corroded or the BIOS chip has failed then you will not get PM_SLP_S4_L and the machine will not boot. Very often this line is corroded by liquid damage. .
definitions.SPI_MOSI_R: What is SPI_MOSI_R? SPI_MOSI_R is a line between the SPI ROM BIOS chip and resistors that sit between it and the PCH. This often corrodes on Macbook Airs due to liquid damage and results in missing PM_SLP_S4_L and no bootup..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V35_S3: What is PP1V35_S3? PP1V35_S3 is a 1.35v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Powers On - Fan Spin - Black Screen / No Post
threads.message:
Hello,

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that powers on with a fan spin, but nothing else. Customer said it just suddenly stopped working. No corrosion found, board looks clean.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.6 volts
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> = 1.8 volts
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL> = 1.8 volts
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH3</SIGNAL> = 1.8 volts
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_GFX_PH1</SIGNAL> = 0.85 volts
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_GFX_PH2</SIGNAL> = 0.85 volts

BIOS
1 <SIGNAL>SPI_MLBROM_CS_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts
2 <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_IO1_WP_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts
3 <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_IO2_WP_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts
4 GND
5 <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_IO0_MOSI</SIGNAL> = 0 volts ?
6 <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CLK</SIGNAL> = 0 volts ?
7 <SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_IO3_HOLD_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts
8 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts

When I plug in the power adaptor, pin 5 and 6 pulses two times to 0.5 - 1 volt and then goes to 0 volts

<RESISTOR>R6122</RESISTOR> / <SIGNAL>SPI_MOSI</SIGNAL> / pin 1 = 0.474 diode mode
<RESISTOR>R6121</RESISTOR> / <SIGNAL>SPI_CLK</SIGNAL> / pin 1 = 0.474 diode mode
<RESISTOR>R6111</RESISTOR> / <SIGNAL>SPI_CLK_R</SIGNAL> / pin 1 = 0 volts / 0.48 diode mode~
<RESISTOR>R6112</RESISTOR> / <SIGNAL>SPI_MOSI_R</SIGNAL> / pin 1 = 0 volts / 0.48 diode mode~

How should I proceed in troubleshooting this board?

Thank you in advance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Powers On - Fan Spin - Black Screen / No Post
threads.message: Removed BIOS and pins 5 and 6 is now 3.3 volts each. Faulty BIOS chip it seems - checked with a programmer and I am unable to get a read from it? Where can I get a clean Rom to flash?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Powers On - Fan Spin - Black Screen / No Post
threads.message:
Instead of wasting time in such manner, did you think to check what happens on the BIOS chip of working board???
No matters what model is.
However, good to have 0V at mentioned pins.

Try this file, as is:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://drive.google.com/file/d/1sS7scELcitDOrHkZscIEtW_ZnIRV5xiu/view?usp=sharing[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Powers On - Fan Spin - Black Screen / No Post
threads.message: I guess I got lucky. This one did the trick with a whole new BIOS chip + clean ME flash.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Powers On - Fan Spin - Black Screen / No Post
threads.message: I was about to reassemble the MacBook after further tests and the MacBook is back to not being able to post. Just a fan spin, responds to power off button, no backlight and that's it. This one is very odd.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Powers On - Fan Spin - Black Screen / No Post
threads.message: Does the board work alone on the desk, but fails mounted on the shell?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Powers On - Fan Spin - Black Screen / No Post
threads.message: It currently fails both when mounted in shell and when board is alone on desk. No output to external monitor either. I tried new BIOS chip + flash several times already so it must be something else.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Powers On - Fan Spin - Black Screen / No Post
threads.message:
CPU gets core voltage?
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> comes high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Powers On - Fan Spin - Black Screen / No Post
threads.message:
Yes, correct.

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> = 1.8 volts
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL> = 1.8 volts
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU_PH3</SIGNAL> = 1.8 volts
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_GFX_PH1</SIGNAL> = 0.85 volts
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_GFX_PH2</SIGNAL> = 0.85 volts
<SIGNAL>VR_PHASE_GPU_VDDCI</SIGNAL> = 0.9 volts

These are consistent and never changing.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts

Other random readings:
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL> = 1.35 volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.05 volts

I checked all SPI bus series termination resistors, it checks out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Powers On - Fan Spin - Black Screen / No Post
threads.message: For random issues, broken trace/solders as possible culprit.
